problem_text:
(J. W. Grossman). The nilpotent-completion diagram of a group G is as follows: G/γ1G ← G/γ2G ← · · · , where γiG is the ith term of the lower central series and the arrows are natural homomorphisms. It is easy to see that every nilpotent-completion diagram G1 ← G2 ← · · · is a γ-diagram, that is, every sequence 1 → γsGs+1 → Gs+1 → Gs → 1, s = 1, 2, . . ., is exact. Do γ-diagrams exist that are not nilpotent-completion diagrams?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: Yes, such γ-diagrams exist (N. S. Romanovski˘ı, Sibirsk. Mat. Zh., 26, no. 4 (1985), 194–195 (Russian)).
